The armor of Oolacile’s finest warriors. Imbued with the power of arcane sunlight, this armor seems to repel shadow from its gleaming exterior.
Effect: Adds 2% Lightning Damage, boosts INT by 3 and STR and DEX by 2.

Hood of a deranged hermit who left the main druidic order. The most extreme of the druids believed that to have power over nature, they must become one with nature. Shedding the shackles of convenience, they lived as hermits. As nature became corrupt, so too did their minds, until only animalistic desires remained.
Effect: applies 10 magic damage on roll

Living armor that was made by combining animal leathers and still-growing branches. The thorns of these branches will damage anyone they comes in contact with, and slowly drain their essence. The method of growing such an armor was perhaps the hermit's greatest achievement, but they had long since abandoned any circles that they could share it with, and by the end, did not care to do so.
Effect: applies 20 magic damage on roll

Wrappings of a deranged hermit, coated in numerous stains. Those who forsook modern life to become one with nature skinned their own kills for armor. These tattered wrappings came from such a kill, and were used to protect the hermit who wore them as they tore through thorned briers to claim rare herbs and blossoms.
Effect: applies 10 magic damage on roll

Leg wrappings of a deranged hermit, long-since caked in mud and blood. Worn for a long time, these tattered strips of leather offered little protection from the enemies, but enabled to wearer to walk through many environments without fear. The direct connection with the soil below allows more powerful casting of primal, druidic magic, a favorite of the hermits.
Effect: applies 10 magic damage on roll

Helm of squires in the lost land of Oolacile. In the land of light sorceries, even their knights were expected to be proficient in magic. Simple and sturdy like the people they once guarded, the vanguards were the first to stand against the Abyss, and the first to fall.
Effect: boosts STR/DEX/INT by 1

Armor of squires in the lost land of Oolacile. While not magnificent in appearance, this armor is light and practical, allowing the wearer both mobility and protection. Imbued with a minor light magic, it allowed the wearer to fight back against the Abyss, a noble but futile effort.
Effect: boosts STR/DEX/INT by 2

Gauntlets of squires in the lost land of Oolacile. Trained in both martial combat and magic, their gloves were thin and flexible, allowing them to quickly switch between their catalyst and their shield. Charged with the protection of their people, the vanguards were loved, even if they were just squires.
Effect: boosts STR/DEX/INT by 1

Thick trousers of squires in the lost land of Oolacile. Vanguards were not just tasked with defending Oolacile, they were often the blades that accompanied pilgrims on their journeys. It is because of these travelers that their armor, and their story, was not lost with Oolacile.
Effect: boosts STR/DEX/INT by 1

To be a famous assassin is inviting trouble. In Vinheim, the greatest assassins were part of an elite society known as the Brotherhood. Known as brothers or sisters, those who wore this mask were capable of killing kings. For the right price.
Effect: Increases weapon damage by 2% and increases DEX by 1. Reduces weapon stamina consumption by 30%.

Armor of the infamous Vinheim Brotherhood. Assassins of the greatest mages, members of the Brotherhood eschewed enchanted armor for more traditional protection. Magic is a tool, and over-reliance creates sloppy habits.
Effect: Increases weapon damage by 4% and increases DEX by 2

Gloves of the infamous Vinheim Brotherhood. These stainless, waterproof gloves were said to be made of wyvern leather. They ensured that neither weather nor blood could squander an assignment.
Effect: Increases weapon damage by 2% and increases DEX by 1

Greaves of the infamous Vinheim Brotherhood. These stainless, waterproof boots were said to be made of wyvern leather. They ensured that neither weather nor blood could squander an assignment.
Effect: Increases weapon damage by 2% and increases DEX by 1

A fine cap, adorned with the feathers of large, ancient birds. Those who wear this hat do so as a mark of pride, as shooting a feather off of such a beast, without drawing its ire, is a feat worthy of Gough.
Effect: Adds additional stamina regen. Increases bow distance by 10% and increases weapon damage by 2%

An armored vest made of leather, fashioned after giants in a foreign land. Infused with the soul of one of these great soldiers, this grants the user the stamina to hold the weight of even the greatest bows.
Effect: Increases bow distance by 20% and increases weapon damage by 4%

Gloves made of a tough leather, tempered by giants. It is said that Gough once felled a calamitous beast with a bare-handed shot. In his memory, these gloves offer greater draw strength, and protect the wearer's hands from their innumerable snapped strings.
Effect: Increases bow distance by 10% and increases weapon damage by 2%

Trousers made of a tough leather, tempered by giants. These light and fashionable trousers trade protection for mobility. To an archer, stance is everything, as even a single misplaced foot can cause a shot to fly wild.
Effect: Increases bow distance by 10% and increases weapon damage by 2%

Crystallized life essence, these crystals are grown from the graves of heretical druids, twisted by their proximity to dark magic. They grow by feeding directly on the essence of the living. Only the desperate or truly mad would rely on such defense, no matter how great.
Effect: Adds 1% Magic Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1% and magic roll damage Reduces weapon stamina consumption by 30% + 5% Max FP

Closest to the heart, these green living crystals pulse softly with the wearer's heartbeat. Originally designed to grow with the wearer, the druids all but abandoned their research in Farron Keep. The jealous protection these crystals offer is all that remains of their original goal.
Effect: Adds 2% Magic Damage, boosts weapon damage by 2% and magic roll damage

Crystal that feeds on the vitality of its wearer to grow, these coat the arms, and offer great protection. Cruel in nature, these magical gemstones desire the essence of living creatures, and subtly encourage their host to hunt more.
Effect: Adds 1% Magic Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1% and magic roll damage

Jagged crystals that aid the wearer's stability, anchoring them to the ground. It is from twisted soil that these crystals were grown, imitations of life, untended for generations by absent masters.
Effect: Adds 1% Magic Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1% and magic roll damage

A hood from a foreign land of ash and snow. Said to have learned cryomancies in an attempt to stop the old Chaos, these warriors served their redeemed queen faithfully. Their fate is unknown, but even chaos cannot so easily claim an abyssal shard.
Effect: Adds 1% Dark Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1% Adds 5% Max FP + 5% Max SP

Robes adorned with an iron mail, forged and frozen in a foreign land. This armor offers incredibly protection against pyromancies, even those of chaos. Through the benevolence and sacrifice of their king, the ivory cryomancers endured until at least the end of the hollow's curse.
Effect: Adds 2% Dark Damage, boosts weapon damage by 2%

Blessed by the Ivory Queen, these gloves harnass the power of the Abyss redeemed. Channeling through a cryomancer's implement is made all the easier, as perfect an answer to chaos as one could hope to achieve.
Effect: Adds 1% Dark Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1%

Metal greaves adorned with white fur. The pet of the Ivory King drove off those unprepared to face chaos' flame. This warm fur is sheered from her descendents, and grants adequate protection from the frost of their home.
Effect: Adds 1% Dark Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1%

Made of a simple and crude steel, the helmet is blackened with ash. Undead Hunters seek to cleanse the land of mindless undead. Though many of their order were faithful to Allfather Lloyd, those that weren’t had no inhibitions towards hunting any undead, mindless or otherwise.
Effect: boosts STR and FTH by 1

Armor of the Undead Hunters. Traditionally, this armor was warded with furtive rituals designed to cause pain to any undead in their vicinity. Some saw this treatment as cruel, and as the world changed, so too did the rituals, until they faded from memory. Now, they rely on solid and heavy armor to defend themselves as they work.
Effect: boosts STR and FTH by 2

Gauntlets of the Undead Hunters. The script carved into these gauntlets is a reminder of the importance of their mission, first ordained by Allfather Lloyd. The curse of undead runs deep throughout many lands, and though the faithful may stumble, such words are a comfort many hold dear.
Effect: boosts STR and FTH by 1

Padded leggings of the Undead Hunters. Made of thick, plated steel, Undead Hunters do not neglect the power of a good kick to down an undead. The weight likewise keeps them sturdy on their feet, steadfast against the innumerable undead that they must cleanse.
Effect: boosts STR and FTH by 1

A hooded mask, embroidered with gold, with eyes that glow with the fires of Chaos. Worn by the Inheritors of Izalith, these servants seek to return Chaos to the world. The light from this mask allows them to see as demons do, for Chaos does not fear the dark.
Effect: Adds 2% Fire Damage Adds additional FP Regen + 5% max SP

The Inheritors of Izalith are primarily women, for they are more resilient to corruption than men. This open dress is emblematic of dessert royalty, the Inheritors blending pyromantic cultures. They seek the prestige of Izalith, even if the Witches were something other than human.
Effect: Adds 4% Fire Damage, boosts DEX by 5 and INT and FTH by 2.

Fingerless, red leather gloves, embroidered with gold. Inheritors of Izalith seek to grasp Chaos directly, reliant on the protection of the ash to resist corruption. Little do they know, Chaos can burn even ash.
Effect: Adds 2% Fire Damage, boosts DEX by 2 and INT and FTH by 1.

Hemmed with gold, this short skirt allows the wearer's skin to touch the flames of Chaos as they wade through their destruction. The magic within the thread renders them immune to mundane fire, and grants great protection against pyromancies.
Effect: Adds 2% Fire Damage, boosts DEX by 3 and INT and FTH by 2.

Made of metal forged in super-heated blood, this hooded mask is worn only by the most devout of Rosaria's faithful. The ritual used to make such a set of armor binds it to the blood of the wearer, and those with incompatible blood find the armor's inherent power sickening and toxic.
Effect: Adds 1% Dark Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1% Adds HP and SP regen

The metal and cloth of these robes are both adorned with red etchings that seem to pulse like veins. Rosaria's highest form of blood magic was unknown even to Aldrich, and, in truth, was a defense to use should the Devourer ever turn his hunger to her. Those bound to the armor are also bound in service to Rosaria, the greatest blood mage.
Effect: Adds 2% Dark Damage, boosts weapon damage by 2%

These vambraces of blood-infused metal are designed to protect the the veins of Rosaria's elite cultists. The spikes on the tips of each finger are mirrored inside the gauntlets, allowing the user ease of access to their own blood for even greater power.
Effect: Adds 1% Dark Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1%

The inner bindings of this piece are spiked, drawing out a bit of the wearer's blood with every motion. Forged by Rosaria herself, this sacred garment is constantly awash with blood, for those who call on such a strength believe to gain more as they are steeped in its source.
Effect: Adds 1% Dark Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1%

This cap was made in reverence to the fungal guardian of the princess of ancient magic. It is said that her words guided the chosen undead in their defeat of the master of the Abyss. This living cap emulates the warmth of a mother's love, and aids the wearer's every strike.
Effect: adds poison to your right-hand weapon

Hooded mask of the Grand Alchemist. The long beak was often filled with dried herbs and flowers, with holes far in the back. This would cover up the stench of chemicals as well as protect the alchemist from breathing in harmful or diseased gasses.
Grand Alchemist is a title used to denote alchemists who have made ground-breaking discoveries. Since alchemy was often poorly understood and ignored, the title was typically either granted from master to journeyman, or simply bestowed upon oneself. As a result, this title is more for one's pride, as that is the only thing that benefits from having it.
Effect: increases power of all bombs by 1%, item discovery by 25% and increases estus recovery by 50%.

Bleached leather coat of the Grand Alchemist. Slightly charred from a plethora of unexpected reactions, this coat is meant to protect the alchemist from the testing of their most hazardous hypotheses. In a land of magic and hollows, the risk science poses is often greatest to oneself.
Grand Alchemist is a title used to denote alchemists who have made ground-breaking discoveries. Since alchemy was often poorly understood and ignored, the title was typically either granted from master to journeyman, or simply bestowed upon oneself. As a result, this title is more for one's pride, as that is the only thing that benefits from having it.
Effect: increases power of all bombs by 1% and item discovery by 25%.

Bleached leather gloves of the Grand Alchemist. Bleaching was a common practice among chirurgeons, as the process prevented leather from absorbing the fluids often excreted by their patients. The same principle applies here, though an alchemist's patients are usually inorganic.
Grand Alchemist is a title used to denote alchemists who have made ground-breaking discoveries. Since alchemy was often poorly understood and ignored, the title was typically either granted from master to journeyman, or simply bestowed upon oneself. As a result, this title is more for one's pride, as that is the only thing that benefits from having it.
Effect: increases power of all bombs by 1% and item discovery by 25%.

Occluded leather boots of the Grand Alchemist. These boots show little sign of the wear of most outfits found in Lothric, as the protection they offer is best suited for specifically controlled environments. Fortunately for the alchemist beyond their laboratory, most enemies don't aim for the feet.
Grand Alchemist is a title used to denote alchemists who have made ground-breaking discoveries. Since alchemy was often poorly understood and ignored, the title was typically either granted from master to journeyman, or simply bestowed upon oneself. As a result, this title is more for one's pride, as that is the only thing that benefits from having it.
Effect: increases power of all bombs by 1% and item discovery by 25%.

Gigantic hat worn by an ancient sorcerer.
Famously antisocial, the original wearer used this to block out noise and people's stares so they could focus on their own thoughts.
Effect: grants additional FP regen. Increases max FP by 2% and decreases sorcery cost by 2%.

Robe worn by an ancient sorcerer.
It is said to have been from their apprentice days at the Dragon School, but it is worn out beyond recognition. The original wearer likely never bothered to change out of it.
Effect: increases max FP by 4% and decreases sorcery cost by 4%.

Apparel worn by an ancient sorcerer.
They are indistinguishable from the ordinary kind worn by travelers.
Effect: increases max FP by 2% and decreases sorcery cost by 2%.

Apparel worn by an ancient sorcerer.
They are indistinguishable from the ordinary kind worn by travelers.
Effect: increases max FP by 2% and decreases sorcery cost by 2%.

The ceremonial attire of a venerated archdruid of the Conclave, now worn but still carefully maintained.
Caimar’s exodus from Vinheim was abrupt, disillusioned by the grasping and self-serving behavior of his former colleagues. He had always maintained that the life of a druid was one of action, bold and unapologetic. He saw the members of the Conclave slowly turn away from this attitude and adopt the positions of sedentary academics, like their once bitter enemies at the School of the Dragon, or become political sycophants, groveling at the table of Vinheim’s aristocracy.
Effect: Reduces FP cost of Conjurations by 6%, reduces weapon stamina consumption by 2% and adds 10% max FP.

The ceremonial attire of a venerated archdruid of the Conclave, now worn but still carefully maintained.
Caimar’s exodus from Vinheim was abrupt, disillusioned by the grasping and self-serving behavior of his former colleagues. He had always maintained that the life of a druid was one of action, bold and unapologetic. He saw the members of the Conclave slowly turn away from this attitude and adopt the positions of sedentary academics, like their once bitter enemies at the School of the Dragon, or become political sycophants, groveling at the table of Vinheim’s aristocracy.
Effect: Reduces FP Cost of Conjurations by 10% and reduces weapon stamina consumption by 4%.

The ceremonial attire of a venerated archdruid of the Conclave, now worn but still carefully maintained.
Caimar’s exodus from Vinheim was abrupt, disillusioned by the grasping and self-serving behavior of his former colleagues. He had always maintained that the life of a druid was one of action, bold and unapologetic. He saw the members of the Conclave slowly turn away from this attitude and adopt the positions of sedentary academics, like their once bitter enemies at the School of the Dragon, or become political sycophants, groveling at the table of Vinheim’s aristocracy.
Effect: Reduces FP Cost of Conjurations by 4% and reduces weapon stamina consumption by 1%.

The ceremonial attire of a venerated archdruid of the Conclave, now worn but still carefully maintained.
Caimar’s exodus from Vinheim was abrupt, disillusioned by the grasping and self-serving behavior of his former colleagues. He had always maintained that the life of a druid was one of action, bold and unapologetic. He saw the members of the Conclave slowly turn away from this attitude and adopt the positions of sedentary academics, like their once bitter enemies at the School of the Dragon, or become political sycophants, groveling at the table of Vinheim’s aristocracy.
Effect: Reduces FP Cost of Conjurations by 5% and reduces weapon stamina consumption by 3%.

The ruby mask of the Witch Hunters of Londor. The reason for wearing such a mask has been lost, but many rumors surround it. Some say rubies are able to purify the corruption of the dark, while the more cynical claim it is to appear forever coated in the fresh blood of dark mages.
Effect: boosts STR, INT and FTH by 1

Reviled in Londor, this armor was worn by Witch Hunters, who ply their trade throughout Lothric and the lands of the lords. Working towards the annihilation of dark magic, they themselves relied on such means for this task, and were labeled as hypocrites.
Effect: boosts STR, INT and FTH by 2

Long gloves used by the Witch Hunters of Londor. They believed that they could reduce their own corruption by minimizing their contact with the dark. There was an understanding among their kind, and those who began to fall to dark’s pull were hunted like any other.
Effect: boosts STR, INT and FTH by 1

The chain skirt and trousers worn often by the Witch Hunters of Londor. Though they hail from the land of hollows, Witch Hunters could be found throughout the world. Unlike Lloyd’s faithful, they believed not in a holy cause, but a never-ending quest for extermination.
Effect: boosts STR, INT and FTH by 1

Crafted from the bones of fallen enemies, this armor has been petrified with the power of geomancy.
Effect: adds 1% Phys damage, boosts weapon damage by 1% Adds 30% Stamina weapon reduction + 5% Max FP

Crafted from the bones of fallen enemies, this armor has been petrified with the power of geomancy.
Effect: adds 2% Phys damage, boosts weapon damage by 2%

Crafted from the bones of fallen enemies, this armor has been petrified with the power of geomancy.
Effect: adds 1% Phys damage, boosts weapon damage by 1%

Crafted from the bones of fallen enemies, this armor has been petrified with the power of geomancy.
Effect: adds 1% Phys damage, boosts weapon damage by 1%

The ruined blindfold of the once proud Legion of Izalith. Though the witch’s pyromancies were often too great for mortals to handle - especially men - those who served them would nonetheless seek mastery of demon’s fire.
Effect: increases Dexterity, Intelligence and Faith by 1.

Regalia of the Legion of Izalith, fallen to ashen tatters in the wake of Izalith’s destruction. The Legion stood as guardians and protectors of their land, giving their lives fully to the witches, demonkind, and the flames of Chaos.
Effect: increases Dexterity, Intelligence and Faith by 2.

Ruined wrappings once worn by the Legion of Izalith. Supposedly, these wraps were once enchanted so that even Chaos could not burn them away, but so long has it been since Izalith was lost that the magic has faded, offering almost nothing to the wearer but a memory.
Effect: increases Dexterity, Intelligence and Faith by 1.

A tattered garment once worn by the Legionnaires of Lost Izalith. The original design was worn by both men and women, emulating the dress of their beloved Witch and her daughters. The thread was spun from the webs of a demonic spider, and was meant to survive, but did not.
Effect: increases Dexterity, Intelligence and Faith by 1.

Tattered and ragged, the once proud regalia of the Forossan sages serves as temporary attire for aeromancers that seek ascension to the skies. A knowledge once thought lost, Aeromancies were returned at the advent of the Nameless King’s Forossa.
Effect: reduces cost of sorceries by 2%.

Once an ornate robe, the wear of wild wind has left this discarded cloak in tatters. Commonly found among apprentice aeromancers, who seek the path to Forossa, home of the greatest aeromancies.
Effect: reduces cost of sorceries by 4%.

To call the remnants of this garment gloves is imaginative, and based largely on their appearance long ago. Offering little in the way of defense, the torn remnants still contain a fractional power, a useful tool for aspiring aeromancers.
Effect: reduces cost of sorceries by 2%.

Adorned in gold leaf, the majority of the waistcloth survived what the rest of the regalia did not. Forossan dignitaries adorned themselves in gold, the ornate metal a reliable weight for anchoring one against their own wind. As for its conductivity, perhaps that is the reason aeromancers do not fly.
Effect: reduces cost of sorceries by 2%.

These masked adornments are worn by geomancers who have abandoned the fading flame. Set apart from the others on the path of chaos and fire, these geomancers have found kinship with the earth. Dusty and worn, they resemble little more than the rags of a mad hermit, perhaps one that has found kinship with demonkind.
Effect: reduces cost of conjurations by 2%

Tattered shawl of those who harnessed the power of earth. Geomancers tied themselves to the fate of demons, and sacrificed their connection to the flame with one of stone and earth. By infusing the ground with just a flickering ember, it answers their call. Dusty and worn, these garments have seen much of the earth, but lack greater protection.
Effect: reduces cost of conjurations by 4%

Tattered cloth gloves worn by geomancers. Constant use of geomancy has an affect not just on oneself, but on the clothes they wear. Unfettered use of a geomancer’s tool to call upon the earth has caused rock to sprout, as if alive, along the left hand. This stone slightly increases protection, and reduces the strain of controlling the earth.
Effect: reduces cost of conjurations by 2%

A tattered cloth, covered in the dust of worked stone. The boots of such a piece were once furred, but have since become as solid as marble, and taken on a similar color. Novice geomancers covered their bodies completely, as earth is volatile, and the dust they were exposed to could tear their lungs apart.
Effect: reduces cost of conjurations by 2%

A pyromancer’s garb, soaking in chaos in the bowels of old Izalith. Kept as a relic of a bygone age, pyromancers of the great swamp revere these garments as a symbol of the still seething power of the mother of chaos.
Reduces FP consumption of conjurations by 6% Increases fire damage by 2% Increased FP regen by 2

A pyromancer’s garb, soaking in chaos in the bowels of old Izalith. Kept as a relic of a bygone age, pyromancers of the great swamp revere these garments as a symbol of the still seething power of the mother of chaos.

Reduces FP consumption of conjurations by 5% Increases fire damage by 3%

While made in Londor, this dark cloth found a home among the aldrich faithful. Never before worn, Archdeacon McDonnel was told to await the arrival of a champion who would unlock the many secrets of the deep and carry forward the will of the great serpent.
Reduces FP consumption of sorceries by 6% Increases dark damage by 2% Increased max FP 10%

Reduces FP consumption of sorceries by 5% Increases dark damage by 3%

These wrappings were made by the warriors of sunlight of Lothric as an homage to the iconic dress of Father Gwyn. The golden crown reflects the rays of the sun and amplifies the power of sunlight.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 6% Increases lightning damage by 2% Increased stamina regen by 5

These wrappings were made by the warriors of sunlight of Lothric as an homage to the iconic dress of Father Gwyn. The golden crown reflects the rays of the sun and amplifies the power of sunlight.

A tattered hood worn by a traveling cleric sworn to Lloyd's Devout.
Allfather Lloyd paid little heed to the "Latter Gods" as he would call them. He instead concerned himself with uncovering the greater mysteries of the gods forgotten by men.
Effect: reduces Miracle FP consumption by 2%.

A once ornate but now threadbare robe worn by a traveling cleric sworn to Lloyd's Devout.
Lloyd would oft criticize the actions of Gwyn, claiming that he was only a "borrower" of the light and that the true source of the light was both ineffable and eternal.
Effect: reduces Miracle FP consumption by 4%.

A soft pair of gloves worn by a traveling cleric sworn to Lloyd's Devout.
Lloyd did not condone the widespread telling of the miracles he and his undead hunters employed. He would remind his followers that "Silence is also a miracle."
Effect: reduces Miracle FP consumption by 2%.

A soft pair of boots worn by a traveling cleric sworn to Lloyd's Devout.
"We must all walk in the path of light and retreat from the darkness. Thou that presume to goodness, shall find no peace upon this path."
Effect: reduces Miracle FP consumption by 2%.

Expertly made from cloth and leather, these traveling clothes from a bygone age seem to lessen the exertions of the wearer. Useful for both combat and exploration.
Effect: Increases weapon damage by 2% Reduces weapon stamina consumption by 30% + adds SP regen

Expertly made from cloth and leather, these traveling clothes from a bygone age seem to lessen the exertions of the wearer. Useful for both combat and exploration.
Effect: Increases weapon damage by 4%

Expertly made from cloth and leather, these traveling clothes from a bygone age seem to lessen the exertions of the wearer. Useful for both combat and exploration.
Effect: Increases weapon damage by 2%

Expertly made from cloth and leather, these traveling clothes from a bygone age seem to lessen the exertions of the wearer. Useful for both combat and exploration.
Effect: Increases weapon damage by 2%

A priest’s hood, worn to show contrition. Priests of the old gods are reduced in number, yet the stories they tell still hold strength.
Ornate yet faded, the Way of White had many such vestments used within their ranks.
Effect: reduces miracle FP consumption by 2%.

An adorned clergy’s robe, it has faded from both use and time. As their numbers dwindled, priests of the old gods worked all the harder in their names.
Ornate yet faded, the Way of White had many such vestments used within their ranks.
Effect: reduces miracle FP consumption by 4%.

Wrappings of white cloth, inlaid with gold, such garments were symbols of priests everywhere. Even now, one can recognize a priest by the way they dress, as if from a lost time.
Ornate yet faded, the Way of White had many such vestments used within their ranks.
Effect: reduces miracle FP consumption by 2%.

The skirt of a priest that flows with a certain elegant dignity. Both men and women of the cloth wore this skirt, in reverence to their gods.
Ornate yet faded, the Way of White had many such vestments used within their ranks.
Effect: reduces miracle FP consumption by 2%.

A hat worn by one of the elusive warlocks that live on the outskirts of Londor.
Witches and warlocks survive on secrecy and by cultivating knowledge of the darkness. With the dark now encroaching on the land, they have become more bold than before.
Effect: reduces Sorcery FP consumption by 2%.

The robe worn by the elusive warlocks that live on the outskirts of Londor.
Though lacking organization, such as that found in Vinheim, warlocks did not greedily hoard knowledge for themselves. They worked as a cabal, and when one made a twisted breakthrough, it was not long before others knew of it.
Effect: reduces Sorcery FP consumption by 4%.

Arm wrappings worn by the elusive warlocks that live on the outskirts of Londor.
Even as the fire burned bright, those who sought the dark powers present within humanity were known to exist. They gathered in Londor, naturally drawn to the darkness of hollows, but could not shed their clandestine ways.
Effect: reduces Sorcery FP consumption by 2%.

Trousers worn by the elusive warlocks that live on the outskirts of Londor.
No warlock understood what the end of their dark path would bring, and few cared. Their proximity to the dark caused most to lose themselves to its corruption. Those that resisted watched as their cabals devolved into practices most twisted, and were often forced to leave.
Effect: reduces Sorcery FP consumption by 2%.

A long black shroud obscuring the features of the wearer. Stained with the blood of profane rituals.
Once the great cathedral was inhabited by the Way of White. Many members of this sect were seduced by the power of the deep even before Aldrich himself. Those that remained either abandoned such a seat of dark power, or embraced the blood of Rosaria, and became the first of her servants.
Effect: reduces Miracle FP consumption by 2%.

A black robe, stained darker by still damp blood.
While the evangelists sought to spread the corrupting message of the deep, Rosaria’s priests of blood sought eternal life for themselves and their mistress. They were often lost to the mad servants of the deep, and it is said among themselves that their mistress still remembers the name of every individual to which she taught the power of blood.
Effect: reduces Miracle FP consumption by 4%.

Stained wraps of cloth, tethered between the fingers by tattered, red strings.
The corruption was slow and insidious, and many never became aware that their holy practices had turned into the most vile and barbarous rites. Their will was no longer their own, now driven by lust for dark humanity.
Effect: reduces Miracle FP consumption by 2%.

Tattered black trousers, accompanied by little more than a skirt of rotted rags.
After their lady arrived at the cathedral, many priests found in her a renewed faith. They saw a future of dark glory, no longer driven to consumption by the deep. Those that cast aside their mindless brothers were welcomed into Rosaria’s fold, to aid their fellow devout in a campaign of blood and tribute.
Effect: reduces Miracle FP consumption by 2%.

Tribal and inelegant, the northern tribes of cryomancers feel no kinship with living flame. Theirs is an inverted chaos, cold and dark. The hood masks their face with a fraction of such a power, shielding them from biting winds and cryomancy alike.
The origins of cryomancy are debated, and some can use such a thing without the taint of dark, as even the Abyss can be changed for good.
Effect: reduces conjuration FP consumption by 2%.

An inelegant padded robe, worn by cryomancers from the northern realms. Their bodies often matched their environment, as cryomancy can make one frigid to the touch.
The origins of cryomancy are debated, and some can use such a thing without the taint of dark, as even the Abyss can be changed for good.
Effect: reduces conjuration FP consumption by 4%.

Even to cryomancers, the fear of frostbite from their home and their magic lead many to wear multi-layered coverings. These gloves are warm and comfortable, but lack any sense of style.
The origins of cryomancy are debated, and some can use such a thing without the taint of dark, as even the Abyss can be changed for good.
Effect: reduces conjuration FP consumption by 2%.

Trousers made waterproof, for their wearer trekked mostly through the snow and ice of the north. Made for warmth and mobility, the only physical protection they offer comes from the padding, and should not be relied upon.
The origins of cryomancy are debated, and some can use such a thing without the taint of dark, as even the Abyss can be changed for good.
Effect: reduces conjuration FP consumption by 2%.

Said to be the trappings of Lloyd himself, these holy garments each symbolize one of the eternal virtues of the Allfather.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 6% Increases physical damage by 2% Increased max FP 10%

Said to be the trappings of Lloyd himself, these holy garments each symbolize one of the eternal virtues of the Allfather.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 10% Increases physical damage by 4%

Said to be the trappings of Lloyd himself, these holy garments each symbolize one of the eternal virtues of the Allfather.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 4% Increases physical damage by 1%

Said to be the trappings of Lloyd himself, these holy garments each symbolize one of the eternal virtues of the Allfather.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 5% Increases physical damage by 3%

A helm worn by the militant acolytes of Allfather Lloyd. Hollows lack reason, but are vicious. Those who hunt them protect their head first, knowing that the mind is the greatest weapon against the mindless.
Effect: Adds 1% Physical Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1% Reduces weapon stamina consumption by 30% + adds HP regen

Plated armor worn by the militant acolytes of Allfather Lloyd. Sturdy and reliable, the weight of this armor was said to signify the weight of their mission, and the duty each acolyte swore to uphold.
Effect: Adds 2% Physical Damage, boosts weapon damage by 2%

Armored gauntlets worn by the militant acolytes of Allfather Lloyd. Made of a blackened metal, it is only through dogmatic cleaning that these have not rusted from the blood of the countless undead slain by their hands.
Effect: Adds 1% Physical Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1%

Chausses worn by the militant acolytes of Allfather Lloyd. Each step taken by those acolytes was yet another vain attempt to save humanity. Even so, they marched on, continuing their thankless work.
Effect: Adds 1% Physical Damage, boosts weapon damage by 1%

This armor is designed in the style of the Lion Knights, a once-mighty order from Forossa. Although the Lion Knights wore heavy armor, they were feared for their blend of quick weapons and aeromantic power.
With the fall of Forossa, the Lion Knight legacy was cut short. The Lion Knights of New Forossa remain untested, but seem more than just simple echoes of an ancient order.
Effect: boosts STR and INT by 1

The padded cuirass and robe of the once-mighty Lion Knights. Forossa was built along high peaks, and its people had to battle air both thin and cold. Despite the warmth and protection such a piece offers, it is surprisingly uninhibiting.
With the fall of Forossa, the Lion Knight legacy was cut short. The Lion Knights of New Forossa remain untested, but seem more than just simple echoes of an ancient order.
Effect: boosts STR and INT by 2

Metal gauntlets, forged after the style of the once-mighty Lion Knights. Forossa had a connection with a race of short, bearded people, who provided them with exquisite ore in exchange for souls. They are all but forgotten, but those that remain left with survivors of Forossa’s fall.
With the fall of Forossa, the Lion Knight legacy was cut short. The Lion Knights of New Forossa remain untested, but seem more than just simple echoes of an ancient order.
Effect: boosts STR and INT by 1

Metal greaves with a padded skirt for warmth, designed in the style of the once-mighty Lion Knights. Forossa was not a place where the station of your birth mattered, as exemplified by one of their greatest generals, Lothian. The Lion Knights did not ornament themselves, in solidarity with their brothers who could not afford to.
With the fall of Forossa, the Lion Knight legacy was cut short. The Lion Knights of New Forossa remain untested, but seem more than just simple echoes of an ancient order.
Effect: boosts STR and INT by 1

Vinheim renegades value both agility and protection. Both are needed if any clandestine mission becomes compromised.
Effect: Increases max FP and SP by 5% Increases magic damage by 2%

Vinheim renegades value both agility and protection. Both are needed if any clandestine mission becomes compromised.
Effect: Increases magic damage by 4% and boosts INT and DEX by 5.

Vinheim renegades value both agility and protection. Both are needed if any clandestine mission becomes compromised.
Effect: Increases magic damage by 2% and boosts INT and DEX by 2.

Vinheim renegades value both agility and protection. Both are needed if any clandestine mission becomes compromised.
Effect: Increases magic damage by 2% and boosts INT and DEX by 3.

Once called painting guardians, the Blades of Gwyn now serve the old lords in a proactive manner. With faces no longer hidden, they roam the land, hunting for those that would subvert the perpetuation of the divine family and those that stand against the linking of the first flame.
Effect: boosts DEX and FTH by 1

Silvered plate, employed by the Blades of Gwyn. As the guardians of the light Gwyn and his descendants bring to the world, they adorn themselves with shining regalia. Stories are often told of their valor, and they readily offer aid to Unkindled Ash on their journeys.
Effect: boosts DEX and FTH by 2

Armored gauntlets, silvered and worn by the Blades of Gwyn. With the power of holy sunlight, they stand against dark’s poisonous corruption of the land. Allies of other servants of the old lords, they act as zealous knights, forever willing to sacrifice themselves for Gwyn’s vision.
Effect: boosts DEX and FTH by 1

This silken skirt covers the silvered greaves of the Blades of Gwyn. Elegant in their actions and dress, these knights seek not just to defend. Having lost contact with their order within Anor Londo, they have sought allies in an effort to retake the seat of their lords, no matter the cost.
Effect: boosts DEX and FTH by 1

Red leather forged in the blood of Rosaria's failed creations, this headdress is worn by high ranking members of Rosaria's cult. The wearer can slowly siphon the infused blood stored in its endless rags, allowing them to regenerate health, similar to the vampires of legend.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 6% Increases dark damage by 2% Slowly regenerates HP

A tattered robe of blood-infused leather, worn by high ranking servants of Rosaria. This robe's profane creation was commissioned by those faithful to Aldrich, but the sacrifice necessary to create such a thing was, in the end, considered a waste.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 10% Increases dark damage by 4%

Gloves infused with the blood of failed spawn, this magical leather has been enhanced to increase the channeling of dark magic. Worn by Rosaria's cultists, these gloves feel warm and wet, as if coated in freshly harvested blood.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 4% Increases dark damage by 1%

These tattered leggings are infused with with blood in a terrible ritual, overseen by Rosaria. This ritual, created in service of Aldrich, uses the blood of failed, inedible spawn. It is through this blood that the higher officials, named after vampires, gain their power.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 5% Increases dark damage by 3%
